case_name: Bisheshwar Dayal Sinha v. Vice-Chancellor of the Bihar University

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 279 of 1964 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 279 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated Dece

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and order dated December 23, 1963 of the Patna High Court in M. J. C. No. 86 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 23, 1963 of the Patna High Court in M. J. C. No. 86 of 1963.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on April 24, 1964 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, C. J.

anchor.surface_text: P. Varma, for intervener No. 1. Dipak Datta Choudhri and A. K. Nag, for intervener No. 2. April 24, 1964. The judgment

facts.text: Writ petition filed by appellant Bisheshwar Dayal Sinha challenging validity of order by Vice-Chancellor of Bihar University directing reconstitution of Governing Body of Rajendra College, Chapra.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition from which this appeal by special leave arises had been filed by the appellant Bisheshwar Dayal Sinha by which he challenged the validity of the order issued by the Vice-Chancellor of the Bihar University directing the reconstitution of the Govern- ing Body of the Rajendra College, Chapra,

facts.text: Rajendra College admitted by Bihar University as a College under section 2(d) of Bihar State Universities Act (Bihar Act XIV of 1960).

anchor.surface_text: The Rajendra College is an educational institution which has been admitted by the Bihar University as a College, as defined in section 2 d  of the Bihar State Universities  Patna, University of Bihar, Bhagalpur and Ranchi  Act  Bihar Act XIV of 1960   hereinafter called the Act  read with Article I of Chapter XII of the Statutes framed under the Act.

facts.text: Rajendra College is a public institution founded by public charities and conducted under the management of a Governing Body.

anchor.surface_text: The said companylege is a public institution founded by public charities and is companyducted under the management of a Governing Body.

facts.text: First Governing Body of Rajendra College formed by citizens of Chapra in a meeting on 31st July 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The first Governing Body of the College was formed by the citizens of Chapra who had assembled for that purpose in a meeting on the 31st July 1938.

facts.text: First Governing Body consisted of 18 members and continued until 24th July 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The Governing Body thus companystituted companysisted of 18 members it companytinued to function until the 24th July, 1940, with additions in the personnel made from time to time by company option.

facts.text: Appellant Bisheshwar Dayal Sinha elected Secretary to the Governing Body on 3rd June 1961, term to last until 31st May 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had been elected Secretary to the Governing Body on the 3rd of June, 1961, and under the relevant rules of the companystitution, his term of office was to be three accademic sessions, and as such, it was to last until 31st May, 1964.

facts.text: Vice-Chancellor passed order on 13th January 1963 removing appellant as Secretary and appointing another person.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, by the impugned order passed by the Vice Chancellor on the 13th January, 1963, the appellant has been removed from his position as Secretary and another person has been appointed in his place.

facts.text: New statutes framed by Vice-Chancellor promulgated on 18th November 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This body of new Statutes came to be pro- mulgated on the 18th November, 1962.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed appellant's writ petition and other similar petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The Patna High Court has, in substance,, rejected the appellants case and has accordingly dismissed the appellants writ petition as well as the other petitions filed by other persons.

facts.text: Bihar Act XIV of 1960 passed in 1960 for establishment of universities at Patna, Muzaffarpur, Bhagalpur and Ranchi.

anchor.surface_text: In 1960, Bihar Act XIV of 1960, which we are describing as the Act in the companyrse of this judgment, came to be passed. This Act was intended to help the establishment and incorporation of affiliating-cum- teaching Universities at Patna, Muzaffarpur, Bhagalpur and Ranchi in the State of Bihar.

facts.text: Amending Acts: Act 11 of 1962 effective 1st March 1962, Act XIII of 1962 on 21st April 1962, Act XVII of 1962 on 16th October 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This Act was later amended by Acts 11 of 1962, XIII of 1962, and XVII of 1962. The first of these Amending Acts came into force on the 1st of March, 1962 the second on 21st April, 1962 and the third on the 16th October, 1962.

facts.text: Vice-Chancellor exercised powers under Section 35 of Act II of 1962 pending reconstitution of Senate, Syndicate etc., for up to nine months.

anchor.surface_text: Section 35 of Act II of 1962 provides for dissolution of the Senate, Syndicate and Academic Council functioning prior to the companymencement of the said Act and companystitution of new Senate, Syndicate and Academic Council in their place. ... pending their reconstitution, the Vice-Chancellor shall exercise their powers ... for a period number exceeding nine months

facts.text: Impugned order directs reconstitution of Governing Body of Rajendra College with immediate effect.

anchor.surface_text: This order purports to direct the reconstitution of the Governing Body of the Rajendri College with immediate effect in order to bring it in companyformity with the provisions of the new Statutes.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Statute 2(4) invalid as inconsistent with Act.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that Statute 2 4  is invalid, and the impugned order passed under it is, therefore, invalid and inoperative.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds part of Statute 3(1) invalid regarding power to dissolve and reconstitute Governing Body of admitted colleges.

anchor.surface_text: That is why we hold that Statute 3 l  in so far as it gives power to the Syndicate to dissolve and reconstitute the Governing Body ... is invalid.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, Patna High Court order set aside, writ petition allowed, restraining respondents from giving effect to impugned order.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the writ petition filed by the appellant is allowed. An order will accordingly be issued restraining the respondents from giving effect to the impugned order  Annexure A ,

facts.text: Affairs of Rajendra College mismanaged, leading to law and order problem, as stated in impugned order but disputed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General has relied on the fact that the Vice-Chancellor was companypelled to pass the impugned order, because the affairs of the Rajendra College were mismanaged and a very grave situation arose ... These statements were, however, disputed by the appellant in his writ petition.

facts.text: Senate purportedly reconstituted in first week of November 1962, notice for meeting on 30th November 1962 issued on 8th November.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case before the High Court was that the Senate had been reconstituted in the first week of November, 1962 and in fact. numberices had been issued to call for a meeting of the said Senate on the 30th November. ... by a numberice issued in that behalf on the 8th November

facts.text: University of Bihar Act (Bihar Act XXVII of 1951) passed in August 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The first Act to which reference must be made is the University of Bihar Act  Bihar Act XXVII of 1951 . This Act was passed in August, 1951,

facts.text: Governing Body constitution amended in 1941, further in 1950, and modified after University of Bihar Act 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Later, in 1941, the Governing Body adopted a companystitution framed by the Principal of the College at its request and that companystitution governed the administration of the companylege. In due companyrse, some further amendments were made in 1950. After the passing of the University of Bihar Act, 1951 ...

The writ petition from which this appeal by special leave arises had been filed by the appellant Bisheshwar Dayal Sinha by which he challenged the validity of the order issued by the Vice-Chancellor of the Bihar University directing the reconstitution of the Govern- ing Body of the Rajendra College, Chapra,

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 10  provides that one of the purposes and powers of the University is to institute, maintain and manage colleges and hostels and to recognise colleges and hostels not maintained by the University.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 prescribes the Officers of the University who, are the Chancellor, the Vice-Chancellor the Treasurer the Registrar the Deans of Faculties the Finance Officer and such other persons as may be declared by the Statutes to be the officers of the University.

Section 16 defines the authorities of the University which are six they are the Senate the Syndicate the Academic Council the Faculties the Examination Board and such other authorities as may be declared by the Statutes to be the authorities of the University.

Section 20 deals with powers and duties of the Senate. Under s. 20 1 , the Senate shall be the supreme governing body of the University and shall have the entire management of, and superintendence over, the affairs, concerns and property of the University shall exercise all the powers of the University, not otherwise provided for, to give effect to the provisions of the Act. Section 20 2  prescribes in particular some of the powers and duties of the Senate amongst them is included the power of making the Statutes.
Section 21 deals with the Syndicate and its composition
s. 22 prescribes the powers and duties of the Syndicate.

Section 30 d  provides that subject to the provisions of the Act, the Statutes may provide for the admission of educational institutions as colleges and the withdrawal of privileges from colleges so admitted and s. 30 e  provides that the statutes may provide for the institution of colleges and hostels and their maintenance and management.

concepts.interpretation: Limits statutes for admitted colleges to admission and withdrawal of privileges, not management or reconstitution of Governing Body.

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for our decision is whether the impugned Statute 2 4  is valid, and if yes, whether the impugned order is justified. We may also have to decide whether the impugned Statute 3 1  is invalid either wholly or in part.

issues.text: whether the impugned order is justified

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for our decision is whether the impugned Statute 2 4  is valid, and if yes, whether the impugned order is justified. We may also have to decide whether the impugned Statute 3 1  is invalid either wholly or in part.

holdings.text: Statute 2(4) is invalid, and the impugned order passed under it is, therefore, invalid and inoperative.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that Statute 2 4  is invalid, and the impugned order passed under it is, therefore, invalid and inoperative. Then, as to statute 3 1 , the Syndicate may have the power to cancel its grant-in-aid to the callege companycerned, but in so far as 3 l  a  seems to companytemplate that if the affiliated companylege refuses to submit to the order passed by the Syndicate dissolving and ordering reconstitution of its Governing Body, the penalty of the cancellation of grant-in- aid may follow, it must be held that that part of Statute 3 l  is invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Impugned Statute 2(4) inconsistent with s.30(d) limiting statutes for admitted colleges to admission/withdrawal of privileges, not amendment/revision of constitutions or management; clear distinction between University-instituted colleges (s.30(e)) and admitted colleges.

holdings.text: The impugned order is invalid as passed under invalid Statute 2(4).

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that Statute 2 4  is invalid, and the impugned order passed under it is, therefore, invalid and inoperative. Then, as to statute 3 1 , the Syndicate may have the power to cancel its grant-in-aid to the callege companycerned, but in so far as 3 l  a  seems to companytemplate that if the affiliated companylege refuses to submit to the order passed by the Syndicate dissolving and ordering reconstitution of its Governing Body, the penalty of the cancellation of grant-in- aid may follow, it must be held that that part of Statute 3 l  is invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order directing reconstitution by nominating persons exceeds even powers under Statute 2(4) (limited to amending constitution) and is void as statute itself ultra vires Act.

holdings.text: Power to make adaptations or modifications under s.60(ii) does not justify the impugned order.

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether the power to make adaptations or modifications justifies the impugned order presents no difficulty, because we have come to the conclusion that the impugned Statute 2 4  is itself invalid, and so, the impugned order must be struck down on that ground. If the statute on the authority of which the impugned order has been passed is itself invalid, the power to make adaptations and modifications cannot help to sustain the validity of the impugned order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adaptation power operates on pre-existing valid statutes; cannot validate new statute inconsistent with Act's substantive provisions like s.30(d).

holdings.text: Statute 3(1) invalid insofar as it gives power to the Syndicate to dissolve and reconstitute the Governing Body of admitted colleges and to cancel grant-in-aid linked thereto.

anchor.surface_text: That is why we hold that Statute 3 l  in so far as it gives power to the Syndicate to dissolve and reconstitute the Governing Body and enables it to cancel its grant-in-aid to an affiliated companylege under 3 l  a  for the reason that the direction issued by the Syndicate in that behalf has number been companyplied with, is invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.30(d) limits statutes to admission/withdrawal for admitted colleges; Syndicate cannot directly dissolve/reconstitute autonomous Governing Bodies, only impose conditions with disaffiliation remedy.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; writ petition allowed; respondents restrained from giving effect to impugned order.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the writ petition filed by the appellant is allowed. An order will accordingly be issued restraining the respondents from giving effect to the impugned order  Annexure A , because the said order, and Statute 2 4  and a part of Statute 3 l  on which it is based are invalid and inoperative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Impugned statutes ultra vires Act; order illegal; High Court erred in upholding validity by ignoring distinction between admitted and instituted colleges.

holdings.text: Vice-Chancellor's action inconsistent even with Statute 2(4) itself.

anchor.surface_text: But what the Vice- Chancellor has done has gone beyond even Statute 2 4  he has not only amended or revised the constitution of the Governing Body, but has also nominated certain persons on it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute 2(4) authorizes only amendment/revision of constitution to conform with new statutes, not nomination of specific persons to Governing Body.

holdings.text: No conclusion recorded on whether Vice-Chancellor's power under s.35 Act 11 of 1962 had ended when statutes promulgated.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the contention raised by the Attorney-General is sound-. On the available material, we see no evidence on which it could be held that a Senate had been reconstituted on any particular date, and so, we do not propose to record any conclusion on this part of the appellants case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insufficient evidence to decide Senate reconstitution date; High Court finding not binding.

Section 30(d) limits statute-making power, addressing whether statutes can claim power to dissolve/reconstitute Governing Bodies.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that Statute 2 4  is invalid, and the impugned order passed under it is, therefore, invalid and inoperative. Then, as to statute 3 1 , the Syndicate may have the power to cancel its grant-in-aid to the callege companycerned, but in so far as 3 l  a  seems to companytemplate that if the affiliated companylege refuses to submit to the order passed by the Syndicate dissolving and ordering reconstitution of its Governing Body, the penalty of the cancellation of grant-in- aid may follow, it must be held that that part of Statute 3 l  is invalid.

The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the writ petition filed by the appellant is allowed. An order will accordingly be issued restraining the respondents from giving effect to the impugned order  Annexure A , because the said order, and Statute 2 4  and a part of Statute 3 l  on which it is based are invalid and inoperativ

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether the power to make adaptations or modifications justifies the impugned order presents no difficulty, because we have come to the conclusion that the impugned Statute 2 4  is itself invalid, and so, the impugned order must be struck down on that ground. If the statute on the authority of which the impugned order has been passed is itself invalid, the power to make adaptations and modifications cannot help to sustain the validity of the impugned order.

The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside, and the writ petition filed by the appellant is allowed. An order will accordingly be issued restraining the respondents from giving effect to the impugned order  Annexure A , because the said order, and Statute 2 4  and a part of Statute 3 l  on which it is based are invalid and inoperativ
